intro: Clarkia amoena subsp. huntiana, commonly known as the Sierra clarkia, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the evening primrose family (Onagraceae) and is characterized by its showy, cup-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pink. The plant typically grows in rocky slopes and open woods, preferring well-drained soils and full sun to partial shade. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are hairy and often branched. This subspecies is known for its ornamental value and is sometimes cultivated in gardens for its delicate appearance.
